replies.author: @loki2240
replies.text:
Yes, it's disgusting. Trans people are a tiny, tiny minority with virtually no political power of their own. Without the support of cisgender people, they are virtually powerless against bigots and bigoted systems. And of course, they're causing no inherent harm by being trans.

I try to call out anti-trans bigots who conveniently switched from being homophobes after same-sex legal marriage became a national phenomenon and Western civilization didn't collapse. They're foul people who need groups to target with bigotry. One typically didn't hear a peep from them about trans people, when bigotry against gays and lesbians was more socially acceptable. But they quickly and vigorously accepted a new target in trans people, when the right wing offered them up.  

They aren't just misguided people - they're foul people who are intent on being foul to certain groups of people. And it isn't necessarily the case that they're no longer homophobes - in fact, it's more likely that they just don't voice their homophobia in mixed company because it isn't socially acceptable in many circles. Look at misogyny - the overwhelming majority of Americans would say that they oppose it and they believe in equal rights for women and girls. Yet, misogyny is still a major problem in our society and blatant misogyny is still often expressed in like-minded social circles. People don't necessarily reveal their true thoughts, when they have reason to believe that they will get a lot of pushback. And as we've seen with Republican politicians, they were quiet about gays and lesbians until they determined that homophobes regained enough power to target gays and lesbians with legislation and case law. Don't make the mistake of thinking that they're only going to target trans people, or LGBTQ people. They're going to continue to target ethnic minorities (especially black people), women, etc. - whenever they think that they have the power to do so.

replies.text:
@miguelitrosmats541 - I disagreed with your favorable opinion of your coworker. I didn't argue that you should've said anything different to him. I think that you did very well, using your trans coworkers to challenge his negative stance. 

And you may not have intended it, but it seems like (in your 2nd post) you were contrasting "culture war" issues, like trans people being able to use the public restrooms of their choice, with "real stuff," like changes to your payroll system. It should go without saying that being able to use public restrooms, being able to seek gender-affirming medical treatment, being able to work and engage in commerce without being discriminated against, etc. are real life issues for trans people and their loved ones. They aren't just abstract concepts to argue about online. And some trans people are married, have kids to raise, etc., too.

replies.author: @loki2240
replies.text:
@jurgnobs1308 - On sports, my cisgender sisters were both (scholarship) college track athletes, and they both support trans girls and women being able to participate in girls' and women's sports.  I know that some cisgender girls or women athletes don't. But the ones I've seen propped up by the media weren't even very good. Like there was a cisgender high school girl who complained about a trans girl participating in a track invitational, claiming that the trans girl kept her out of the finals of her event and cost her a chance at a scholarship.  Again, this was an invitational - not a state championship or a national meet. This cisgender girl wasn't going to increase her chances of getting a college scholarship by finishing 8th instead of 9th at an invitational. And there were 7 other cisgender girls who were also faster than her and "kept her out of the finals." 

And a common theme in the opposition to trans girls and women in girls' and women's sports is the notion that trans girls and women are just Mike Tyson, Michael Phelps, or Usain Bolt wearing a wig. And included in that is the notion that all males are inherently better in all sports than all females.  My sister, who was a sprinter, was faster than almost all boys and men. And she wasn't even one of the fastest female sprinters in the nation at any level. But the overwhelming majority of males aren't fast sprinters. And a trans girl or woman isn't necessarily fast, either. Even if she is, it isn't necessarily because she's trans.

A woman is an adult female human. Prior to adulthood, a female human is referred to as a girl (a female child or adolescent). Denoting the sex that can bear offspring or produce eggs, distinguished biologically by the production of gametes (ova) which can be fertilized by male gametes. Women inherit a pair of¬†X chromosomes¬†from their parents, and are capable of¬†pregnancy¬†and giving¬†birth¬†from¬†puberty¬†until¬†menopause. More generally,¬†sex differentiation¬†of the female fetus is governed by the lack of a present, or functioning,¬†SRY-gene on either one of the respective sex chromosomes.¬†Female anatomy is distinguished from male anatomy by the¬†female reproductive system, which includes the¬†ovaries,¬†fallopian tubes,¬†uterus,¬†vagina, and¬†vulva. The adult female¬†pelvis¬†is wider, the¬†hips¬†broader, and the¬†breasts¬†larger than that of adult males. Women have significantly less facial and other body hair, have a higher body fat composition, and are on average shorter and less muscular than¬†men.

A¬†man¬†is an adult¬†male¬†human.
Prior to adulthood, a male human is referred to as a¬†boy¬†(a male¬†child¬†or¬†adolescent). 
Like most other male¬†mammals, a man's¬†genome inherits an¬†X¬†chromosome¬†from the mother and a¬†Y¬†chromosome¬†from the father.¬†Sex differentiation¬†of the male fetus is governed by the¬†SRY¬†gene on the Y chromosome. During puberty, hormones which stimulate androgen production result in the development of¬†secondary sexual characteristics, thus exhibiting greater differences between the sexes. These include greater muscle mass, the growth of facial hair and a lower body fat composition.

@patternrecon5271 That's easy. The earliest *written* record of what we now call trans people is found in the karma Sutra, over 2,400 years ago. The real one, the religious and philosophical text,  not the soft core knock off for middle aged white people. They were referred to as the tritriya pakriti, and if you know anything about SE Asian history during the next millennia plus, you'll know that Indians and their Kama Sutra made it all the way from India to Indonesia (skipping China, Japan, Korea, and basically just all of East Asia), spreading their religion and philosophy the entire time. 

Coincidentally, every place they touched back then has an uninterrupted history of trans people or third genders (or sometimes many more than 3 genders) that continues in most of those regions even today. 

Almost as old is the tradition of the hijra, another name for a trans woman. But they're legally considered a gender in places as varied as Nepal, Pakistan, India, and Bangladesh to this day, even appearing as an option on passports. 

So there we go. More than two thousand years of largely  uninterrupted existence of trans people, covering quite literally almost half the damned globe. And these are *far* from the only examples, but since you only asked for one from over a millennia, and I gave you two (actually, *way* more than two if you're at all familiar with the areas mentioned), I guess we'll see how true to your word you are. 

I don't have high hopes, but we'll see.

replies.author: @82abhilash
replies.text:
@leomorris7573 You are comparing personal taste to identity? That is absurd. Because identity is objective, while tastes are subjective. If a person claims to be a man or  a woman, it can be tested by examining the genitals or checking the chromosome pairs. Identity is not simply a matter of trust.

Be that as it may, it is not wise to blindly trust people when it comes to claims even about personal tastes.There are frauds who use such techniques to try to get your confidence and then swindle. Real trust takes time to build.

Which brings me to your case. What about claiming to be trans? It cannot be verified. So a person can lie about being trans and one can never know. So are you lying about being trans? There is no way to verify. But let me tell you this, if you believe your claim to be trans, you were most likely swindled. 

"why would someone radically reshape their entire life and relationships with other people, end up tangled in an obnoxiously complicated medical system?" It is a good question, and I can answer it. To start with,  you do not have to do any of that to claim to be trans. Just declare that it is what you are and you can enter any public bathroom you choose. An open invitation to perverts. So the question about pretend trans is very important.

Let it be so, called trans-people end up doing the radical reshaping in many cases. That is one of the objectives of those that propagate this ideology, so it makes sense. So why do people go through it? They were induced to do so.  Because they and their parents are tricked into beleving that if they don't do it, you will end up committing suicide. It is a simple scare tactic, but it works. Meanwhile your body has been irreversibly changed with all the "therapy". You have become their milch cattle. Now you are entrenched in this delusion and even if you free your mind, your body is broken forever. Still, most people don't fall for the bait, but you did.

You are not the target here. You are just a pawn. Not used by the conservatives, but by the so called liberals who use you to accumulate power on your behalf. Conservatives are worried that the same blackmail will be used by the medical mafia to target their child. Their actions are purely defensive. Children are not mature enough to make decisions on this matter, so parents do responsible parenting.

replies.author: @geroffmilan3328
replies.text:
@jsrodman approaching exteme hair-splitting there, mate.
If it wasn't technically a malady, there would be no associated medical treatment/remedy - but there is, and in my view those who wish that treatment deserve it, without any opinions from pricks like Walsh or Shapiro.

The underlying mistake there is to apportion negative status to disorders.

Otherwise: it is just as wrong to abuse language by using a prefix like "trans" as a definition., as it is to say "discrimination" if you mean "*baseless* discrimination".
"Trans-gender person/people" is probably best.

In the words of Isaac Brock:
"Language is the liquid,
That we're all dissolved in,
Great for solving problems,
After it creates the problem..."

replies.author: @jubies6286
replies.text:
@C4lmaria There's no benefit to muddling terminology like this. Gender dysphoria is a bodily illness, with physical causes, and physical treatments. Trying to dance around that fact just makes it easier for people to argue that the treatments shouldn't be considered medically necessary.
Plenty of other ailments have also been weaponized against people who have them; the solution has never been to stop treating them as illnesses. Recognizing dysphoria as a disease doesn't need to mean treating trans people themselves as a blight, any more than recognizing diabetes as a disease necessitates treating diabetics as a blight.

replies.author: @C4lmaria
replies.text:
@jubies6286 uuuuh actually we have made an effort to change weaponized terminology
For example, the derrogatory use of "leprosy" drove the medical community to start using "Hansen's" over the former to refer to the disease

replies.author: @C4lmaria
replies.text:
@jubies6286 you miss the point that recognizing diabetes as a disease implies in considering diabetes inherently and necessarily a bad thing for the person's health (which it is), regardless of not treating them as blight
In the same logic, treating "transgenderism" as its own disease would imply in considering being transgender as inherently and necessarily a bad thing for the person's health (which it is not), which is already wrong and deleterious by itself, regardless of whether you treat them nicely or not.

replies.author: @C4lmaria
@jubies6286
replies.text:
@C4lmaria Dysphoria is inherently a bad thing for a person's health. Being born with the wrong neural wiring for your body is going to cause dissociation at best, and serious distress at worst.
Although just to clarify, I'm not suggesting we call it "transgenderism" which is a made up boomer word for it that borders on being a slur. The person I replied to in my initial comment was suggesting people stop using the phrase "gender dysphoria" altogether and stop treating it as an illness, so that's what I was responding to.

@C4lmaria I guess that's more apt for someone whose dysphoria totally evaporates after surgery, where the only follow up needed is to ensure they heal correctly and don't develop osteoporosis or other complications of losing their endogenous sex hormone production. But bear in mind that that's not universal; there's a lot of things hormones and surgery just can't fix, especially for people who don't start transition until well into puberty or in adulthood. And for people pursuing a nonbinary transition without reassignment surgery, taking meds to suppress their natural hormones and keep dysphoria at bay is, again, a lifelong necessity. For many, maybe most, there will always be some level of dysphoria, and it remains a lifelong condition to manage.

Also you're right that it isn't exactly right to call it a disease. Disorder of sex development would be more accurate. But either way, broadly speaking it's definitely not incorrect to call it a malady. And there's still no good reason to drop the term "gender dysphoria." Even "gender identity disorder" (since, it is a disorder) would be a fine term, if not for that term's unpleasant history.

A woman is an adult female human. Prior to adulthood, a female human is referred to as a girl (a female child or adolescent). Women inherit a pair of¬†X chromosomes¬†from their parents, and are capable of¬†pregnancy¬†and giving¬†birth¬†from¬†puberty¬†until¬†menopause. More generally,¬†sex differentiation¬†of the female fetus is governed by the lack of a present, or functioning,¬†SRY-gene on either one of the respective sex chromosomes.¬†Female anatomy is distinguished from male anatomy by the¬†female reproductive system, which includes the¬†ovaries,¬†fallopian tubes,¬†uterus,¬†vagina, and¬†vulva. The adult female¬†pelvis¬†is wider, the¬†hips¬†broader, and the¬†breasts¬†larger than that of adult males. A¬†man¬†is an adult¬†male¬†human.

Like most other male¬†mammals, a man's¬†genome inherits an¬†X¬†chromosome¬†from the mother and a¬†Y¬†chromosome¬†from the father.¬†Sex differentiation¬†of the male fetus is governed by the¬†SRY¬†gene on the Y chromosome. replies.author: @silentotto5099
replies.text:
‚Äã@superbarnie You write about "conservative ideas", but I suspect what you really mean is "religious ideas" or, more specifically, religious ideas embraced by conservatives.
I don't think it's at all clear such ideas have been "proven".  They've existed, for sure, and society has survived.  So, I suppose they're "proven" in that sense.  But, the choice of the word "proven" implies something more, doesn't it?  It suggests that the society based on such conservative ideas was just, equitable and benefited all of its citizens.  I think a strong case can be made that past societies based on such conservative ideas did not meet those ideals.
As to your comment regarding "state authority" vs "parental authority" with respect to education, you're missing the point.  
Children have an independent right to have access to the best available information.  The state's role is to ensure that right is protected, even when the parents would deny that right.  The state isn't usurping parental authority, it's guaranteeing the rights of children.
I realize that results in the undermining of many of the ideas held by religious conservatives, but that's just the nature of the beast.  While it was originally written is a bit of snark, the statement "Reality has a well known liberal bias." contains a great deal of truth.

replies.author: @superbarnie
replies.text:
‚Äã@silentotto5099 Well, no. I don't mean religious ideas, although religion as an institution was created to preserve conservative ideas. The conservative ideas I am referring to are religion agnostic. As an example, let's look at the topic of sex and gender norms, which seems to be the hot topic on this video comment section. You will find that roughly equivalent, traditional ideas of the masculine and feminine, and corresponding gender roles, existed in, and structured society in all prosperous civilizations throughout history, regardless of their respective religions. The modern, radical gender ideology posits that there are a cornucopia of fluid gender identities and that biological sex is irrelevant or in fact inscrutable; which is in stark contrast to the principles recognized by every successful civilization up to this point. These ideas are so evolutionarily unsound that they have only become economically and socially viable in very recent times, ironically, through the economic and social progress of those whom we deem backwards and unsophisticated. Therefore, I am skeptical of the long-term viability of such radical ideas.
     I agree that children ought to have access to the best learning materials, ideally. Clearly, that is a proposition that anyone can agree with. But, how do you determine what is the "best available information"? By what standards are you determining that? And who exactly is in charge of determining that? You seem to be happy to have other people's children taught things against their parents will so long as it conforms to your ideology, but if the situation was reversed, would you be okay with your child being taught ideology you strongly disagree with with? Lastly, considering how inefficient, ineffective, and corrupt governments programs tend to be, do you really want them to have ultimate authority for your children's education?

replies.author: @superbarnie
replies.text:
@tgamagedon I am not sure that I am understanding your point properly. Are you suggesting that trans people attempting suicide is a existential threat to the United States? Because that seems like a ridiculous notion to take at face value.
  Not to be too calloused, but the United States has flourished since the beginning without any significant population of "trans" people. I don't really think a lack of trans population would be an existential threat to the United States.

replies.author: @Nerdsammich
replies.text: @superbarnie Hard disagree about gender roles being a relative constant. Even within the same culture, gender roles are in constant flux. The brewing of beer was women's work until the alewives started talking about forming their own guild. Chickens and eggs were women's work until the Depression when wives started supporting the farm with egg money. There's a similar story with midwives being pushed out by doctors, though medicine is swinging back toward women as they overtake men in higher education in general, and STEM in particular. Remember, that's just within English-speaking western nations. If you look at different cultures, things diverge more.

replies.author: @tgamagedon
replies.text: @superbarnie I'm as always astounded how unable you are to distil an idea from an analogy. I guess I will stop using them for your sake. My point was, that ideas can and should be challenged regardless of how much they've "stood the test of time". If our understanding on a topic advances, we don't need to wait 50 years to see if it is still relevant. Yes there is ideas, which have persisted, because they have merit, but there are also those which persist, because they help maintain certain power structures. Royalty, and race are concepts, that persist, because they benefit powerful interests at the expense of an underclass. Not dismantling them, because they have benefited some, ignores the suffering they have necessarily inflicted n others.

Any racial group has more internal genetic diversity than what is supposed to separate them, who does and does not belong to a racial group has always been flexible depending on who is needed to preserve majority power (Irish, Italians and eastern Europeans have all been essentially folded into whiteness, to undermine solidarity between them and black people as an underclass and prevent their uprising) and don't even get me started on how flattening the entirety of south America, including natives, Spanish, Portuguese, whoever immigrated there essentially before 1960 and all of their mixing offspring into one racial group is completely idiotic. Over the years race has served to justify slavery, segregation, apartheid and other systems that designate black people as a permanent underclass, divide the lower class to prevent them uniting against powerful interests, justify exploiting people and recourses outside the "western world" and paint those people essentially as savages for revolting against that exploitation, justify wars over recourses and influence, I could keep going. Race has only has any relevancy today, because it is useful to the right people, not because it points to any real distinction between people.

replies.author: @superbarnie
replies.text: @Cheesemonkey2889 Look, no amount of abstruse intellectual gymnastics is going to convince someone that something they can see plain as day with their eyes does not exist. Races are characterized by a distinct set of shared phenotypes within the group, through an extensive period of group inbreeding. Even if there are more genotypical variance within a race, in no way does that mean the differences between races do not exist. Sure, the formation of races mostly had to do with groups being geographically inaccessible to each other; and with the advent of modern transportation and widespread racial miscegenation, perhaps in a hundred generations, the term will become meaningless. But to say that race does not exist right now is just wishful thinking.

That's the american concept of race in humans and people don't mean ethnicity or anything else when they say it. A woman is an adult female human. Prior to adulthood, a female human is referred to as a girl (a female child or adolescent). Denoting the sex that can bear offspring or produce eggs, distinguished biologically by the production of gametes (ova) which can be fertilized by male gametes. Women inherit a pair of¬†X chromosomes¬†from their parents, and are capable of¬†pregnancy¬†and giving¬†birth¬†from¬†puberty¬†until¬†menopause. More generally,¬†sex differentiation¬†of the female fetus is governed by the lack of a present, or functioning,¬†SRY-gene on either one of the respective sex chromosomes.¬†Female anatomy is distinguished from male anatomy by the¬†female reproductive system, which includes the¬†ovaries,¬†fallopian tubes,¬†uterus,¬†vagina, and¬†vulva. The adult female¬†pelvis¬†is wider, the¬†hips¬†broader, and the¬†breasts¬†larger than that of adult males. Women have significantly less facial and other body hair, have a higher body fat composition, and are on average shorter and less muscular than¬†men.

A¬†man¬†is an adult¬†male¬†human.
Prior to adulthood, a male human is referred to as a¬†boy¬†(a male¬†child¬†or¬†adolescent). 
Like most other male¬†mammals, a man's¬†genome inherits an¬†X¬†chromosome¬†from the mother and a¬†Y¬†chromosome¬†from the father.¬†Sex differentiation¬†of the male fetus is governed by the¬†SRY¬†gene on the Y chromosome. It's even more sinister than that. Listen closely to what each one is saying again. Rogan asks Walsh if this is happening to, "prepubescents," and the response is, "Yeah, minors". But those are not the same thing. While all prepubescents are minors, not all minors are prepubescents. Rogan completely fails to notice the rhetorical trick and lets Walsh get away with it.

I'm a cis hetero man who has been standing with trans people for years. I made my first trans friend (in real life, not online) ~15 years ago now; he knew he was never alone as long as I was around, and the same goes for all other trans people I meet.

This current sideshow is the last gasp of Republicans, trying to leverage made up culture war nonsense to help boost their ever shrinking numbers. It won't work any better this time than every other time they've tried it, but it's going to take a lot more people paying attention to make sure. Trans people are such a small number of people in reality (vs what the right wing noise machine tries to tell people), that they just can't do it alone. I just hope more people realise that and start making their numbers known.

replies.text:
A woman is an adult female human. Prior to adulthood, a female human is referred to as a girl (a female child or adolescent). Denoting the sex that can bear offspring or produce eggs, distinguished biologically by the production of gametes (ova) which can be fertilized by male gametes. Women inherit a pair of¬†X chromosomes¬†from their parents, and are capable of¬†pregnancy¬†and giving¬†birth¬†from¬†puberty¬†until¬†menopause. More generally,¬†sex differentiation¬†of the female fetus is governed by the lack of a present, or functioning,¬†SRY-gene on either one of the respective sex chromosomes.¬†Female anatomy is distinguished from male anatomy by the¬†female reproductive system, which includes the¬†ovaries,¬†fallopian tubes,¬†uterus,¬†vagina, and¬†vulva. The adult female¬†pelvis¬†is wider, the¬†hips¬†broader, and the¬†breasts¬†larger than that of adult males. Women have significantly less facial and other body hair, have a higher body fat composition, and are on average shorter and less muscular than¬†men.

A¬†man¬†is an adult¬†male¬†human.
Prior to adulthood, a male human is referred to as a¬†boy¬†(a male¬†child¬†or¬†adolescent). 
Like most other male¬†mammals, a man's¬†genome inherits an¬†X¬†chromosome¬†from the mother and a¬†Y¬†chromosome¬†from the father.¬†Sex differentiation¬†of the male fetus is governed by the¬†SRY¬†gene on the Y chromosome. During puberty, hormones which stimulate androgen production result in the development of¬†secondary sexual characteristics, thus exhibiting greater differences between the sexes. These include greater muscle mass, the growth of facial hair and a lower body fat composition.

replies.author: @RevShifty
replies.text:
@CellaDragon I've sat on this for a couple days, wondering how to describe what happens. It can be kind of complicated, and if you've never been around someone who argues a lot, but in a variety of ways using a variety of methods, it might not make a lot of sense. 

I call them out every time. How I do it varies by what context they're saying something in (someone I work with vs someone I passively know in a casual setting vs total stranger while shopping, which has happened), what exactly they said, who they were targeting, what their claim is, etc. But I still call them out every time. 

But it helps that I enjoy arguing (it's almost like being on an adult debate team, but with actual stakes), I can think on my feet well, I can be well spoken if the situation is better served that way, and I'm not afraid of a fight, so intimidation doesn't work. But it's not always explicitly confrontational; it can be very fluid and dynamic, more soft exposure than anything, it can be a series of common sense analogies, a simple reminder that someone simply existing isn't exactly a bright or healthy thing to be upset by, or it can turn to yelling and mocking on a dime. 

It mostly feels like a responsibility. I look like an asshole, so I've learned to use that when people decide to kick down at the marginalized. It's not fair that my opinion matters more to some people than those of someone from a marginalized group, but that's reality so I try to use it to my advantage. And I call them out *every* time, because the groups these people target aren't large enough to fight back on their own (part of what makes them convenient targets in the first place), and they damn well shouldn't need to be defending their own existence to total strangers 24/7/365. Just the very idea is disgusting to me.

I've changed some minds, and also gotten some people to *never* discuss anything remotely political around me again. Which both count as wins in my book.

replies.author: @dansamarco1610
replies.text:
I think that online spaces and "real life" were once two basically separate things, and that they slowly began to merge, so slowly that we didn't even notice it because we were so immersed in one or the other or both. The time we are living in now is an almost alchemical transmutation of those spaces, where they have almost entirely unified and become a new thing that we don't yet have a word for. This idea is parallel to another wherein computers/phones/internet have become a sort of addon for our prefrontal cortexes (obviously not literally but close enough), where search functions/youtube/wikis/social media have fused with our conception of what it even is to be a human.

Thanks for coming to my TED talk, Marx was right, and have a nice day.

replies.text:
@tristanband4003 Yea that worked great for Weimar Germany.  Facists and Communists in the streets creating violence and instability, leaving the average Joe to pick between what they viewed as the lesser of two evils. 

Are  you under the impression that no left wing movement has ever been taken too far to the extreme, resulting in terrible consequences?  That is just a narrative used to promote extremism.  Its like the trend of right wingers who twist facts to say the Nazis were socialists.  The deeper implication is that if Nazis weren't right wing, there is nothing on the extreme right that should prevent people from just going more and more to that extreme.  You can't lose sight of the fact that every ideology is capable of evil, which is proven by history.

"People talk about the middle of the road as though it were unacceptable. Actually, all human problems, excepting morals, come into the gray areas. Things are not all black and white. There have to be compromises. The middle of the road is all of the usable surface. The extremes, right and left, are in the gutters."
-Dwight D. Eisenhower

replies.author: @tristanband4003
replies.text: @rayquaza1245 Spare me Eisenhower. The violence the left was doing was strictly defensive in Weimar Germany. The Right started all of it.

replies.author: @rayquaza1245
replies.text:
@tristanband4003 Do you just see everything as a black and white, left is good right is bad?  The reality of Weimar Germany is layered and complicated.  After the 1917 Russian Revolution, it began spreading to Germany.  By 1918 Germany was in a full blown Communist Revolution, and this was before the NSDAP even existed let alone had popularity.  Don't take this as me blaming the Communists, because like I said it's layered and complicated.  It's just to point out that your narrative of the right starting everything, and the left was only defending itself is a dishonest oversimplification.

Weimar Germany aside, how can you say that it's not possible for left wing movements to be taken too far to the extreme?  Are you unaware of any examples of it happening?

replies.author: @tristanband4003
replies.text: @rayquaza1245 The revolution was broadly popular among the working classes.

replies.author: @rayquaza1245
replies.text:
@tristanband4003 Many Germans wanted the war to end, but it's hard to know how many of those people were just social democrats vs actual communists.  But this point is not relevant to your comment about all the violence being initiated by the right, and the left did nothing but defend themselves.  

However I would like to focus back to your original point, that it's always better to keep going further left, implying that it's always good no matter how far to the extreme you go.  Can you elaborate on this?  I don't see how you can think this.

replies.author: @jsrodman
replies.text:
I'm feeding the derail I know, but most people who detransition do it temporarily.  They detransition until a later point in their life when they can transition with more support and confidence.   However, there are people who detransition and stay de-transitioned, and these people deserve our support and gender affirming care just s much as everyone else.  Criminalizing trans-ness does not help people who eventually detransition, it only alienates and harms them.

I will also point out that transitioning does not mean surgery, and never did.  Thus detransitioning also does not mean surgery.  It's possible that some might be involved, but it's pretty rare, as our gender affirming care is designed with altogether too many hoops to jump for people to go down this path due to being fooled or peer pressured as the hate brigade claims.

replies.author: @amazin7006
replies.text:
@cyber_rachel7427 You are misinterpretting my comment. The other guy was claiming gender is purely a function of arbitrary socialization, therefore gender can be anything.  I'm saying it MUST be permanent and physiological in some way or else your position falls apart.  The republican argument of "well i wanted to be a power ranger when i was that age" becomes true because purely social things can be reversed through simple therapy and exposure. 

The big studies were one study showing the hypothalmus in transwomen shows activity comparable to ciswomen in the presence of male pheromones.  However it's worth noting gay men also have the same variations, and the study didn't account for if they were on estrogen or not. Another study detected grey-matter volume variations in the angular gyrus, the insula,  the insular cortex, and the putamen.  These brain regions are hypothesized to be relevant in transgender people because they are related to the neural network of body perception (not gender).

Studies that have attempted to recreate these finds have turned up with conflicting results. Few autopsy studies have confirmed some of the conclusions.

Right now the science is indecisive, and there is debate about the etiology of gender dysphoria. You have to go with the theory presented earlier to make sense of your positions.

replies.text: it'll, at the very least, make them stronger--or at least it can. one of the genuinely beautiful things, as fucked up as that is to say, about discrimination and oppression is it gives you perspective. it teaches you a fact of the world most of the privileged aren't privy to, and that's the fact that the world is unjust, and we have to fix it. it also teaches you that you can survive. you've done this before. you had to fight adults, strangers, even your own family at times and you're still here. it may suck, but you ARE still here. and people are rooting for you. struggle is not something i think we should romanticize to the extent that we see it as a virtue or something necessary and aspirational. but i do think that struggle CAN be good, and furthermore if tempered the right way, can be a shortcut to years of wisdom in a short amount of time. i grew up working class, black, and neurodivergent; you bet i mf fought everyone including the adults growing up. and now i know how to do it.

replies.author: @charlesparr1611
replies.text:
@malum9478 I hope you reads this whole comment, and take it to heart, because you have fallen into a very VERY dangerous fallacy, you are buying into a myth which is incredibly damaging to the victims of these events and of these. monstrous people.  Your post makes it plain that you do not bear ill will for trans and gay people, and that you mean your words to provide a measure of comfort, and perhaps a scrap of consolation that at least something good will come of their pain. Brace your self, friend, because as I mean to be blunt:

Check your fucking privilege.  Do you even know what the privilege is that you hold? I don't think you do, which is honestly to your credit, as if you did, then your post would border upon victim blaming. And I don't think that's you.  In this case, your privilege is the luxury of viewing this from a perspective of survivorship bias, because that whole cliche about how 'what doesn't kill you makes you stronger', is a big streaming pile of bullshit.


What doesn't kill you leaves trauma, scars, irrational fears, economic disadvantage, wasted time in critical early periods of your life.


Look, I am really really glad things turned out for you, and I have some idea of how real your struggle was, and you deserve to be proud of your success.  But had none of those obstacles been thrown at you, you would be much STRONGER now, because all of that beat you down, and stole your potential, and you're one of the few who can say they 'won'.  You didn't win, though.   You just lost less, evaded some damage.  Had you grown up middle or upper class, neurotypical, and white, you might easily be a senator, or a billionaire.   A little adversity is healthy, but we are not discussing issues that constitute 'a little adversity'.   If somehow republicans were trying to pull this shit on cis-het kids we would be rounding them up and trying them in courts, it constitutes egregious violations of their human rights, the kind that sent nazis to the gallows, the difference is (so far) merely one of degree, and the power to stuff them into ovens. The underlying ethical framework and constructed morality of these guys is essentially that of the people who conceived of and constructed the 'final solution'.  This does not HAVE a bright side. This is NOT a learning opportunity.  Reassuring platitudes implying that 'getting through this' will make these victims 'stronger', when in fact most will be broken by it, and none will be stronger than they would have been if we as society never allowed them to be so viciously abused.



I hope you will read this, and take it to heart, as I said above, I believe your heart is very much in the right place here, but this is a belief that needs to die.

replies.author: @amazin7006
replies.text:
‚Äã@Orang_Himbleton Man you're trying really hard to make this money analogy work but it really doesn't lmao. People can unlearn money, people cannot unlearn gender (or at least that's what the current mainstream treatment plan says, there is some debate within academia about the etiology of GD). This is the whole basis for why HRT is given as treatment for GD instead of purely therapy, because researchers and psychiatrists treat symptoms as if they are emergent from properties in the brain rather than socially emergent.

"but that doesn‚Äôt debunk the idea that gender is socially constructed." 
I'm not debunking this necessarily. There is so little research in gender dysphoria that this might actually turn out to be entirely true in the coming years. My problem is rather that you are holding two contradictory beliefs at the same time. 1. The idea that your gender is socially conditioned into you, and 2. the idea that people cannot unlearn being trans. You cannot believe these two things at once. Either both are true or both are false.

If gender is truly socially contagious, then this current treatment plan would be incorrect and the republicans would be right. For any other deadly mental illness it would be unacceptable. Like imagine treating an anorexic person by modifying their bodies to be thinner and smaller.

replies.author: @Orang_Himbleton
replies.text:
@amazin7006 You know, the money analogy worked perfectly for what I wanted to use it for, but I‚Äôll just drop it since you‚Äôre running it into places I didn‚Äôt mean to take it. The point is social constructs can have meaning and rules.

‚ÄúMy problem is that you are holding two contradictory beliefs at the same time. 1. The idea that your gender is socially conditioned into you, and 2. the idea that people cannot unlearn being trans.‚Äù
I was going to say I accept 1 and reject 2, but now that I think about it, these two things don‚Äôt contradict each other. If someone‚Äôs gender is socially conditioned into them, then that doesn‚Äôt necessarily mean that they can unlearn that behavior. At most, it means they could‚Äôve just never learned that behavior in the first place. Like, growing up, we‚Äôre shown images of the sun as being this yellow ball with spikes coming out of it. Later in life, we know that‚Äôs not actually what the sun looks like, but that doesn‚Äôt mean we can just get rid of that conception of the sun.
But I will still say I accept 1 and reject 2 because there‚Äôs no getting around the fact that our conception of gender is obviously shaped around social concepts, hell, you yourself haven‚Äôt even posed an alternative. But the reason I reject 2 is not that we can just go in to someone‚Äôs brain and miraculously change their entire perception of gender, it‚Äôs that we could imagine a world in which some ideas surrounding genders are flipped or completely erased, which would lead to some people who would otherwise be trans, not feeling that initial dysphoria that would otherwise lead to them being trans. I don‚Äôt think this is even that unpopular of an opinion, I remember Contrapoints saying something pretty similar in one of her videos. There‚Äôs no ‚Äútrans soul‚Äù or some shit, it‚Äôs just a figure of speech trans people like to use to express who they fundamentally are.

But also, saying this doesn‚Äôt prove conservatives right about anything because I think that we should construct policy under a utilitarian framework, so I think any treatment‚Äôs on the table as long as it helps people.

As for your comments regarding treatment for biological disorders, a ‚Äúchemical imbalance‚Äù theory has not been proven for depression, and yet we still assign antidepressants to people. You could maybe say that treatment‚Äôs to a completely different degree and problem than anorexia, but I feel like we‚Äôre just arguing about where to draw the line, at that point.

In summary, all I want are two things from you. 1. Prove to me that trans-affirming procedures do more harm than good, and 2. Prove to me that gender comes solely from people‚Äôs brains. I‚Äôm not asking for proof that some people‚Äôs brains behave one way, and other people‚Äôs brains behave another, I‚Äôm asking for proof that outside of any form of interaction with society or social situations, something lights up in some person‚Äôs brain that basically says ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a man, so I should do manly things‚Äù. That‚Äôs the only way you can prove gender is biologically rooted.

text: Republicans in Utah have broken up the voting districts in the major city, Salt Lake, even after initiatives to have an independent entity redraw them. Proposals and promises happened, but in the end, Republican lawmakers did what they wanted, and took pieces of the city and fused them with suburbs and rural communities far away that they know can be relied upon to always vote conservative. Salt Lake is by no means a liberal place, but it's much more accepting than the rest of the state. It makes me sad to see my home broken up and helmed by people more hateful than I can bear. It only makes it feel worse when there are people like Cox, or Romney, are our only "compassionate" officials. If their passive nature can be described as such. Men who seem to be so committed to their religious ideals of compassion and love, but won't denounce those in their own party actively harming others.

replies.author: @Pfhreak
replies.text: The only way to fix that is to make the populous counties (most of the Wasatch Front and probably Washington County) single-county districts, bundling the rest of the state into the minimum number of contiguous, multi-county districts possible to ensure every district is a multi-seat district and then implementing some variety of proportional representation. Ensure Utah and Davis Counties return a Dem or two along with their dozens of Republicans and that Salt Lake County actually returns a majority of Democrats in line with how their voters vote. First-past-the-post voting fundamentally does not yield democratic results and letting the pols have any say at all into what their own districts look like lets them chose the voters instead of the voters choosing them. Prop 4 was a nice attempt, but I knew even as I voted for it that it wouldn't be enough to keep the Republicans from gerrymandering themselves into perpetual supermajorities.

author: @wolfumz
text:
I found the whole premise of Walsh's movie annoying.  Any freshman college student who has taken philosophy for general education requires will tell you, there are lots of simple sounding questions which become irrevocably tangled when you actually think about them.  This happens all the time in philosophy... and asking, "what is a woman?" Is posing a philosophical question.

You can just as easily elicit confused answers from people by asking, "what is a person?" Or "what is a color?" Or "How do you know if something is true?" People can turn themselves into pretzels answering these questions, particularly if you come prepared with pointed objections or counter examples.  It is not hard to do.  That doesn't mean these concepts are illegitimate, or even that they are irrational.  

In the same way, Walsh's movie doesn't actually say _anything_ about the legitimacy of trans identity, much less legal human rights for trans youth.  It's pandering, and pretending there is a fake crisis afflicting millions of teen girls.

replies.text:
A woman is an adult female human. Prior to adulthood, a female human is referred to as a girl (a female child or adolescent). Denoting the sex that can bear offspring or produce eggs, distinguished biologically by the production of gametes (ova) which can be fertilized by male gametes. Women inherit a pair of¬†X chromosomes¬†from their parents, and are capable of¬†pregnancy¬†and giving¬†birth¬†from¬†puberty¬†until¬†menopause. More generally,¬†sex differentiation¬†of the female fetus is governed by the lack of a present, or functioning,¬†SRY-gene on either one of the respective sex chromosomes.¬†Female anatomy is distinguished from male anatomy by the¬†female reproductive system, which includes the¬†ovaries,¬†fallopian tubes,¬†uterus,¬†vagina, and¬†vulva. The adult female¬†pelvis¬†is wider, the¬†hips¬†broader, and the¬†breasts¬†larger than that of adult males. Women have significantly less facial and other body hair, have a higher body fat composition, and are on average shorter and less muscular than¬†men.

A¬†man¬†is an adult¬†male¬†human.
Prior to adulthood, a male human is referred to as a¬†boy¬†(a male¬†child¬†or¬†adolescent). 
Like most other male¬†mammals, a man's¬†genome inherits an¬†X¬†chromosome¬†from the mother and a¬†Y¬†chromosome¬†from the father.¬†Sex differentiation¬†of the male fetus is governed by the¬†SRY¬†gene on the Y chromosome. During puberty, hormones which stimulate androgen production result in the development of¬†secondary sexual characteristics, thus exhibiting greater differences between the sexes. These include greater muscle mass, the growth of facial hair and a lower body fat composition.

replies.author: @wolfumz
replies.text:
@letsrodeo99 my dude, asking "what is a woman?", then following up by reciting a dictionary definition, that's not a discussion.  That's being closed minded.

 I have my doubts that you could fairly summarize the other side of this argument.  Walsh certainly didn't in his movie.  If you can't accurately summarize the other side of an argument, then you don't understand what they're saying.  And if you don't understand it, you're not actually answering it, much less refuting it.

I remember reading a survey that was part of a psychological study on political beliefs.  One of the things this survey found was that American conservatives stood out in an unusual way: they viewed their own political beliefs as being factual.  Everywhere else in the first world, and all along the gamut of the political spectrum, people tended to see their political and social beliefs as differences of opinion and perspective.  US conservatives distinguished themselves here.  They routinely confused their political beliefs to be statements of fact.  Whether it was on abortion, LGBTQ, gun control, small government, or evolution, to them, their views were incontrovertible facts, readily verified as objective truth for anyone who cared to look.

 I'm often reminded of that when I see people posting dictionary definitions, as another poster just did, perhaps thinking they are saying something we don't already know.  Repeating a dictionary definition in this context amounts to failing to penetrate the surface level of this issue.  You're just bouncing off the surface.

@meatpuppet5036 ah, the classic, "it's common sense."  Well, maybe it's self-evident to you, but it's not self-evident the rest of us.  It seems I don't possess common sense.

Undergraduate philosophy is a fair contender here: Simone de Beauvior's "The Second Sex" adequately answers most of Walsh's objections.  De Beauvior helped to create existentialism alongside Sartre.  The book is considered entry level reading on this topic. 

No one said detransitioning / wrongful transition is not a problem, or that is not serious. It is very serious.  What I said is that's a fake crisis, in that, it's a fake crisis on a social level.  Utah GOP campagined, debated, and passed a law (twice) which effected a single trans high school student.  This is weird.  You don't plan your whole life around the chance you might be struck by lightning.

Take the Rogan clip where Walsh is wrong by an order of magnitude.   I work as an engineer.   I imagine if I worked on a project for several years, but when someone asked me a basic question about the rate of incidence, I gave number that was over a thousand times too large, that would look pretty bad.  That would normally ring alarm bells.  But when Matt Walsh does it...?

It's not wrong to say, "a thousand or a million, it's still important."  But it's kind a seperate issue from me point that Walsh sucks, he's wrong about salient matters of fact, and he's just playing a game throughout his movie.

replies.author: @carllewis9771
@wolfumz
replies.text:
@carllewis9771 there's a difference between the true rate of incidence and the rate of diagnosis.  Cultural stigma depresses the rate of diagnosis, not because they are fewer trans people in fact, but because they aren't going to the doctor/therapist.  You can see this effect comparing country by country: the Netherlands and Denmark have a diagnosis rate that's basically right on the estimated true number, while the state of Iran infamously announced they have zero trans women (and zero gay people, for that matter).  Stigma effects reporting rates.

The net number of teens getting services or treatment for being trans remains really small.  Japan had 2 firearm homicides one year, and 6 another year.  No one was melting down over how the number tripled.

I believe you do have a growing number of kids who transitioned when they shouldn't have.  In the past, this was exceptionally rare, but today, it's become less rare, and you have this population of young woman who transitioned to live as men, only to find they weren't trans men.  I think there's something going on there, and we should take it seriously.   In an ideal system, this wouldn't happen.  But this is it's own issue, IMO.

 Matt Walsh wants to know what a woman is, The Second Sex explores the question and has excellent observations.  De Beauvior makes arguments in that book that are tame today but were radical at the time (ie, women should be be allowed to pursue happiness outside of the house or their obligations to their husband).  It's good reading.

If you want something more practical, maybe Fausto Sterling's book "Sexing the Body" would be helpful.  One of the core ideas of that book is that our categories of sex, defined by chromosomes and egg cells and the like, are constantly being defied by nature.   As a biologist, she points out all these examples where biology does not fit with our mental model (for example, if a women is born without egg cells, we would still think of her as a full woman, or even fully female).  

There are deep questions about how much these biological categories are clinical desciptions of nature, and how much they are figments of the human mind.

replies.author: @wolfumz
replies.text:
@carllewis9771 ¬†I have no idea.  Maybe?

My deeper point- and maybe I am saying something you already know- is that these folks in the comment thread who are regurgitating the dictionary definition are failing to penetrate the surface layer.  They're missing the whole thing.

You, however, have penetrated the surface.  You rightfully question: what is the relationship between egg cells and femininity?  How are these two things connected?  The answer to that question is not going to he found in a dictionary or a biology reference text.  And it's certainly not found in Walsh's movie.

Biology matters, but social roles matter too.  And social roles are products of the human mind.

Take the example of "parent."  A parent, in biology, has a strict definition.  You can check paternity using genetics.  Animals have parents, planrs have parents, and amoebas have parents.

So, are parents who adopt their children "real" parents?  They plainly don't fit the definition of biological parents.  Does that mean they are being delusional and unreasonable, if they expect me to call them parents?

No, obviously not.  That's because being a parent is also about what you do.  There is a social and psychological definition, in addition to the biological definition.  We can make a distinction between biological parents and adopted parents, but I don't think there's any good reason to say that adoptive parents are not parents.

I think gender can work the same way.  Yes, we have a biological meaning for sex.  But we also have a social and psychological meanings.  Sometimes they match up, and sometimes they don't.

replies.author: @SarastistheSerpent
replies.text:
@dansstreet the NYT article was full of disinformation. I was on a puberty blocker 15 years ago for adrenal hyperplasia. They‚Äôve been prescribed to kids with endocrine disorders since the 80s without any controversy. There is ZERO evidence that they affect personality in any way whatsoever (something like that is usually immeasurable anyway unless it affects cognition, which puberty blockers definitely do not), and the chance for lower bone density than average is so rare that there is clinical doubt whether the reported cases are even the result of puberty blockers at all. In any case, patients are warned of this potential side effect before being prescribed. So it‚Äôs a non-issue.

The issue of trans women in sport is also a non issue, since essentially all sporting bodies prohibit trans women who have not undergone at least 2-5 years of HRT to compete. Certainly all professional sporting bodies have this rule, and many even prohibit trans women (and cis women as well) who have experienced any part of male puberty from competing, which means the only trans girls competing in those sports have no androgenic advantage whatsoever.

It‚Äôs not a ‚Äúknee jerk‚Äù reaction for leftists to say that this is alt-right propaganda and disinformation. It straight up is alt right propaganda and disinformation. As someone who is not trans but was on a hormone blocker for adrenal hyperplasia, the recent hysteria about them is particularly upsetting to me. Where was your outrage about them the last 40 years? Why now do you find them controversial? Let‚Äôs not hide behind false concern here. You just don‚Äôt like trans people, and you think trans people are fake. The reference to transgender women as ‚Äútranswomen‚Äù is a particularly telling dog whistle, as there is no such word or concept as ‚Äútranswoman‚Äù. Trans/transgender is an adjective, not a noun, and woman/women is a noun. There are trans women and there are cis women, just as there are tall women and short women, but there is no such thing as a ‚Äútranswoman‚Äù just as there is no such thing as a ‚Äúshortwoman‚Äù.

Trans women are women in the same way that short women are women. Trans women don‚Äôt merely ‚Äúidentify‚Äù as women, they simply are women. Trans is merely an adjective. Please do not invent fake words and assign them to demographics you dislike.

replies.author: @thepuncakian2024
replies.text:
I'm completely fine if you someone is 18 and they want to medically transition, or really do anything they want to their bodies. They're legally adults, so they should be allowed to do with their body as they choose. If a kid even wants to dress as the opposite sex, I'm fine with that too. Dressing in different clothes isn't going to physically mess them up. But when it comes to medically transitioning kids, that's where I, and I think many others, draw the line. I have heard the argument many times that denying kids gender affirming care can be dangerous, that they might kill themselves before they get to 18, and I definitely understand that concern, but surely there is a way that trans kids can have their suicidal thoughts lessened without resorting to physical transitioning right? I feel like these avenues haven't even been looked into because to some people doing so means they are removing a part of their identity, akin to gay conversion therapy. Personally, it has confused me that trans is lumped in with LGB because to my knowledge, being lesbian, gay, or bisexual does not entail wanting to mutilate yourself to alter your physical form, but being trans often can. Gay conversion thereapy doesn't help the recipient because they most likely weren't going to mutilate themselves anyways. But if there is some sort of "trans conversion therapy" if you even wanna call it that, that exists out there, that has little to no side affects and stops the gender dysphoria, so that they don't want to hurt themselves for feeling like being in the wrong body anymore, then in my view that is objectively a net positive. I fear that this line of thinking that trans people shouldn't try to get rid of the gender dysphoria through other means aside from physical transition could percolate into other areas of mental health and send us backwards. For example, could we get to a point where psychopaths and sociopaths should not try to be treated with medication because that is repressing their true identity?

Of course everyone deserves rights, whether they are classified as having a mental illness or not. I'm not even advocating for legislation to stop people from transitioning if they want to. People should be allowed to make their own choices. But my point is instead of going full speed ahead on this front, maybe we should slow down a tad and think about what we are doing before we continue.

replies.author: @Liloldliz
@Liloldliz
@Liloldliz
replies.text:
@thepuncakian2024 Finally, I understand why people are worried that affirming care for trans people might be the same as affirming care for people with body dysmorphia, but I think linking it to psychopathy (which we call antisocial personality disorder now btw) is a real stretch because that causes harm to other people.
If you think about it, the goal of healthcare is always to improve the health of the patient and prevent harm to the patient and others. 
In the past, trans healthcare was centered on convincing people not to be transgender in the same way that homosexuality was seen as something to be cured. So therapy for LGBT+ people was all about trying to make them "normal".
To be blunt, it didn't work. It's now called "conversion therapy" and it has a very low chance of actually improving people's health and relationships. It resulted in a high suicide rate and even drug use as a coping mechanism. 
It was harmful.
That's why we give affirming care, which is what works to improve the health of the patient without harming them or people around them.

replies.author: @Liloldliz
replies.text: @thepuncakian2024 anyway sorry that was so long, but I read your whole comment and understand where you're coming from. I guess my point is that we already tried conversion therapy and it didn't work and made things a lot worse. And that the reason LGBT has so many different kinds of people included, is because we have all been seen as outside what is "normal" for gender and sexuality and we've all been treated with conversion therapy in the past, and harmed by it. So we stick together and stick up for ourselves and each other to try and make all our lives better, including for people who are growing up now as LGBT so they can have it easier than we did.

replies.author: @thepuncakian2024
replies.text: @Liloldliz To my knowledge, puberty blockers can only be used up to a certain age, right? Like 14 or so I think? Then at that point they have to decide whether to get on hormones or proceed with their biological puberty right? And if they choose to go through with hormones, some of those changes are permanent and nonreversible?

replies.author: @thepuncakian2024
replies.text: @Liloldliz So is your point that being trans itself is not a mental illness, but having gender dysphoria is? I mean that makes sense, but aren't the two intrinsically linked? Like gender dysphoria is a byproduct of being trans, correct?

replies.author: @thepuncakian2024
replies.text:
@Liloldliz Like I was saying before, I guess it really boils down to how we see identity and mental illness in general. If believing you were born as the wrong sex is not a mental illness, then would believing you were born as the wrong species, as with therians as I believe they are called, not be a mental illness either? Should we be providing species affirming health care to them in that case? Like what is the difference there? 

From a purely practical standpoint, I understand that if the only way to get rid of gender dysphoria in a person is to provide gender affirming healthcare than so be it. Better that then they be harming or killing themselves. But I posit simply if there was a way to get rid of gender dysphoria without hormones or surgeries if people would even be open to it, or if it would be shot down immediately for trying to change who they really are. Like I said before, hypothetically there is a pill that's developed that stops feelings of gender dysphoria, one which has little effects, on par with the side effects of an antidepressant let's say, would people be open to the idea of taking it?

replies.author: @Liloldliz
replies.text: @thepuncakian2024 gender dysphoria is something most trans people experience. It's treated with transition and affirming care, and then that person is still trans, but their mental health is better. Does that make sense?

replies.author: @thepuncakian2024
replies.text: @Liloldliz Yeah that makes sense, but would you consider gender dysphoria a mental illness then, as it causes the person mental pain?

replies.author: @Liloldliz
@Liloldliz
replies.text: @thepuncakian2024 puberty blockers can theoretically be used at any age, and we actually sometimes use them to treat cancer in cisgender adults, but that's a long story. But yes, often by mid teens it's appropriate to start affirming hormones. Some of the effects of hormone treatment are reversible, some aren't - same as cisgender puberty.

@Liloldliz Gotcha, so its from a purely pragmatic standpoint. If it is shown with evidence to work, then go with it. If something better is found, then go with that. 

So in the case of therians, perhaps in the future if it is found that changing their physical attributes to align with the species they identify with works in reducing their dysmorphia, then that should be the standard treatment plan going forward?

author: @dylanintefilin
text: that quote about the isolation a person feels when every day you don't know if your existence has been criminalized‚Äîthat's something i feel very deeply. i'm a queercrip trans jew in school currently to be a high school spanish teacher in the state of kentucky. i was born and raised here, i love this state to pieces. right now the plan is to get my teaching certification here, and to teach at a public school here. but i've had to line up backup plans in case suddenly i'm not allowed to teach in this state anymore. it's weird, when i talk to people about my career plans, i always have to mention that i have these backups set up, and i see the looks on their faces when it dawns on them that this is a lived reality for people like me. the whole thing that got me into teaching was realizing how important having a nonbinary role model would have been for my younger self‚Äîi'm one of that attempted suicide statistics, maybe i wouldn't have been if i had known successful and happy nonbinary adults. i want to be that person here in the state of kentucky, because it's needed here. but if it becomes illegal for me to do so, i'll have to move elsewhere. i can't help but think about all the kids i'd be leaving behind if that was the case. let's hope it doesn't get to be like that

replies.author: @RevShifty
replies.text: That's terrible, but I wish you the best of luck. That is an admirable goal, and you could offer a lot of good to people in an otherwise terrible place (emotionally, socially, etc; not Kentucky specifically).

replies.author: @dylanintefilin
replies.text: @RevShifty thank you :) <3

@Kamfrenchie "I did a quick check , and cosmetic seems an word for this? cosmetic implies it's only there for the sake of beauty?"

adjective
involving or relating to treatment intended to restore or improve a person's appearance.

Yes, when we look at secondary sex traits, like breasts or vagina, we don't look at them and immediately associate their actual biological function with them. Do you? when you see a woman who is presenting very womanly do you just go. "Ah she has the milk producing glands on her chest so she most likely is able to give birth."?

"Well, it sounds like another fallacy i'm often seeing. 
In that sense, are you also going to say we dont base the category of human by whether they have functiunning organs ?"

No, you're obfuscating and deflecting. What I'm saying is not a fallacy because. We can generalize the typical traits that we associate with man or woman as genders.
But we as a society do not broadly engage with the definition in a way that someone literally stops being a woman if their uterus does not work or their breast are destroyed or even MEDICALLY if they might have an odd chromosome match.
Now if YOU do this, that's your own personal preference, and I can't really change this but medically.
We do not reduce the category of women down to being able to give birth or not.

A sterile woman, is still a WOMAN. Her sterility is simply a secondary feature that can be used as a descriptor because she's still a WOMAN. Because again, we do not 100% base the category of man or woman on biology.

"You need to have a baseline so you can then be able to tell when something is unusual or wrong. Otherwise, how can you tell that someone missing body parts, and covered in blood, is wounded and in need of help, if you dont reccognize the baseline human as having x feature ?"

This isn't about baselines, this is about whether definition can fit different categories of people. If your definition of gender is that it's sex which is chromosomes and genitalia all of the time. Then you innately are ignoring a chunk of people who are effectively cis or "biological" women who mismatch this definition.
So medically this definition wouldn't work because it's once again inconsistent.

"Please specify, this is interesting. It's yoour perspective as man that makes you a man ? What do you mean ? And in your example, did  you mean that like, someone performed an extensive surgery to change your body then ? Because then yes, you would still be a man. "

Not just my perspective, it's both the combination of my internalized perception due to the underlying innateness of how my brain works, along with the outward gender I express as. These two things align making me cis, if I was suddenly given xx chromosomes, I wouldn't be a woman. If I was then given a vagina and uterus, I would still not be a woman.
Because I am a man, if you're agender that's fine but for me and a decent amount of men, I think this answer is pretty consistent.

If someone just started calling me a woman I wouldn't be a woman.

Now if you're talking about sissy hypno shit where my brain is femininized or something then I'm not engaging with that because I'm not into gender bender kink shit.

"Here is the thing, to many of us who are criticals of the notion of gender being used so widly, the gender affirming care is basicly a new version of lobotomy based on intimidation of critics, and questionable sciences, and bad studies, especially when applied to minors."

It's not, you're just wrong, literally every single study on this done on adults shows that gender affirming care is the BEST treatment for gender dysphoria, if you disagree. You have no scientific grounding to stand on really, this is a fact broadly.

author: @somedudeok1451
text: I used to think that material conditions, rather than ideology, are always a completely sufficient explanation for the behaviour of political groups. But I can no longer believe that in the face of what's happening. Rather, sometimes it seems that fanatically evil ideology can not only contribute alongside material conditions to certain outcomes, but even in some cases become the leading cause in creating atrocities.

replies.author: @starwarfan8342
replies.text: BREAKING NEWS: a Marxist finally recognises the concept of personal responsibility

replies.author: @somedudeok1451
replies.text:
@starwarfan8342 What? Ideology is not about personal responsibility at all. Using personal responsibility as a framework to explain sociological phenomena remains a stupid and deeply liberal approach. An individual may gravitate towards a certain ideology because of their material conditions, but I realize that this ideology may possibly act as a motor to drive social change (for better or worse) by itself. It still all goes back to material conditions though.

Do NOT rely on the concept of personal responsibility to analyse trends on a societal scale. All that allows you to do is point the finger at _individuals_ and demand angrily that they "be better", while missing the _bigger_ picture.

author: @theoriginalt-paine3776
text: Lmao, ah yes, I forgot all about the ‚ÄúRed Wave‚Äù that was supposed to be coming last year. Listening back to that clip, followed up by your lovely German accent saying ‚ÄúAnd what happened?‚Ä¶ Republicans got fuckin‚Äô trounced.‚Äù Made me genuinely belly laugh. All the anti-trans stuff is just so absurd that it puts off even people who aren‚Äôt very supportive of the trans community. There are plenty of working class people who most leftists would view as transphobic, and probably rightly so, because they‚Äôre very out of touch with the LGBTQIA+ community, they don‚Äôt understand trans issues, they don‚Äôt always use the right pronouns, and they think & say all sorts of problematic things, but despite all of that they have no desire whatsoever to see trans people legally oppressed, they see no reason to prevent trans people from transitioning, etc, because they are all too aware that the existence & acceptance of trans people has absolutely zero negative effects on their lives, and while that lack of personal effect on them means they have no desire to come out in strong support of trans people, it also means they have no desire to come out against trans people. At the end of the day, they don‚Äôt really care about trans people because they aren‚Äôt effected by trans issues, and no matter how hard Republicans try, they cannot force those people to care about those issues, and come out against them. Trans people are an extremely small portion of our society, they always have been, and they always will be, and as a group they are totally harmless. That is a shame insofar as it means there aren‚Äôt legions of people from every corner of society coming out in support of them, it also protects them to some extent because it makes it very hard for the right to rile people up against them. I live in hope that, as a result of how poorly this bigoted nonsense plays with the majority of society, it will soon lead to the separation of the coalition of the money people & the evangelical whack jobs that has made up the Republican Party since the late 1970s, and that the Republican Party will take the side of the money people over the evangelicals. Evangelicals are a small minority within our society, and they have entirely too much political power. They are the one group of people who actually need to be disenfranchised because they hold way more power than they should based on the percentage of the population they account for.

replies.author: @jasonbrody5270
@jodo2785
replies.text:
@jasonbrody5270 That's called gender dysphoria, a subsection of body dysmorphia 

Treatment would depend on further analysis because dysphoria can often be a symptom of other conditions like PTSD or various anxiety disorders. 

Group therapy and individual counseling would be standard practice . . .  horomones can be given if there is an underlying horomone imbalance . . .  antidepressants are often used as well 

I can gurantee you that elective HRT and cosmetic surgeries are NOT effective treatments, because they yield no positive clinical effects whatsoever. Rates of depression and suicide are (thus far) completely unchanged by those practices.

Other disorders involve "acting a certain way" . . . yet their treatments don't involve encouraging those acts. Anorexics are not encouraged to lose weight, despite thinking and acting like someone who is obese.

For every other mental condition in existence, self determination doesn't trump reality.

Personally I believe "acting like a woman" is just "acting like yourself"  . . .  gender is inherently indeterminate, it constantly changes in both the general and individual sense. Therefore, it is useless for personal identification.

Gender is something we should get rid of, rather than expand upon it like some kind of irrational cult.

M . . .  F . .  I. Male, female, intersex. Those terms should have no effect on who you are as a person . . .  only WHAT you are as a person. Because human biology is concrete fact, and nothing else.

replies.author: @BigHenFor
replies.text: @Chri5t0ph3rBr0wn Is Nature Conservative in your terms? Be ause Auntie Corona, and every living thing on the planet is evidence that it is not. And forgetting that we are products of Nature too, is our real problem. Change is the only constant. What we are arguing about preferences, and who gets to set those preferences in society. Your choice to follow "conservative" preferences is a subjective choice. You do you. That too is a preference. You prefer not to wear corsets and a bustle too. But that too, was once conservative dressing. But it's not now. But why should ones preferences become social rules? Why should they have the force of laws? These are questions, amongst many others that have plagued all societies, and the answers are not settled ones. They change. Societies evolve, but for some the speed of change, and the consequences of change induce anxiety, or even fear. For others, less so. As civilised people, we should be able to discuss these changes, and decide collectively on our approach, but it gets tough when that debate is hijacked for political gain. And that usually happens in societies, whose politics are adversarial, rather than collaborative, and therefore tend towards conflict and instability. And there are people who cannot resist taking advantage of that. What makes it easy for them is that quite natural range of responses to change, and the complexity of actually being human in an uncertain universe. Its stressful, and people tend to vary in how well they can deal with that. There will always be unknowns, but not everyone can handle that. So we agree on conventions to simplify things, so as not to stress us out. They may not reflect reality completely, but we content ourselves with them because it's easier. That is what culture is. Culture is not objective reality, its an edited map of reality, with omissions, simplifications, and stuff that is just plain wrong, purposively designed to enable specific collective goals. And it is often drawn by those with power and influence. And your freedom to dress as you do, is another convention, that's been replicated over years. But nothing stands still.

author: @Medytacjusz
text: This kind of reminds me of the situation in Poland post-WW1. The right wingers were also so sure of absolute victory in Presidential elections they were totally stunned that the center-left candidate (Gabriel Narutowicz) won. They stirred up mass hysteria that the election was "stolen" by "foreigners" (the Polish minorities, esp. Jews, who overwhelmingly voted for Narutowicz) and in the end, days after taking office, a crazed right-winger painter shot the newly appointed President, which became a step in Poland's descent into authoritarianism later down the line. You can see the similarities, right? Confidence in victory, disappointment, bigoted scapegoating, hysteria -> death and violence. Same pattern of right-wing (anti)politics happening for a 100 years and more, across the world.

Great to see you on YouTube again, I've been waiting for a new video! Minor language note: English doesn't have a true system of genders like in other languages, with it mostly being the pronouns. That said, "he" is for male people, "she" is for female people. But "it" uniquely doesn't refer to people, but to objects. 

The default gender neutral pronoun is "they" as legally from before Shakespeare, it has been used to refer to persons unknown but specified.

replies.author: @rogirek3362
replies.text:
@danniuwu8628 This is still wrong, though. It is, and should be, an infectious ideology. Just like feminism. Just like racial justice. Just like any other form of humanism.
There are social experiences and issues that are statistically aberrant within trans, trans-male, trans-female, and non-binary demographics. Being black doesn't constitute a purely medical issue, and neither does being trans. Ideology must be crafted to address the inequities associated with those demos if they're ever going to be addressed, and unless they are proactively "shoved down the throats" of conservatives, the ideologies are useless.
Not all ideas are made equal, and bad ideas should be forcibly expunged to protect the disenfranchised. Refusing to accept this is tantamount to agreeing that oppression should continue.
Trans issues are primarily social, and are definitionally political. How often do you hear trans people complaining about being unable to get healthcare? Pretty often, I see it around. How often do you hear trans people complaining that the Republican party is trying to have them murdered in the streets by vigilante .pdf hunters? A lot more.
It's literally a question of identity. It's a political issue.
